questions.title: I
questions.article:
Two artificial marshes were built to help reduce the amounts of iron and manganese in, and the acidity of, water seeping into a stream from a coal mine site (see Figure 1). Table 1 shows precipitation, in centimeters (cm); flow rate, in liters per minute (L/min); pH (acidity); and iron and manganese content, in milligrams per liter (mg/L), of inlet and outlet water over 5 days.



Water having a higher level of iron or manganese or a lower pH than the values given in Table 2 is said to be contaminated.
questions.question: 1. Which of the following figures best represents the iron concentrations at Outlet 2 for the 5-day period?

questions.title: I
questions.article:
Two artificial marshes were built to help reduce the amounts of iron and manganese in, and the acidity of, water seeping into a stream from a coal mine site (see Figure 1). Table 1 shows precipitation, in centimeters (cm); flow rate, in liters per minute (L/min); pH (acidity); and iron and manganese content, in milligrams per liter (mg/L), of inlet and outlet water over 5 days.



Water having a higher level of iron or manganese or a lower pH than the values given in Table 2 is said to be contaminated.
questions.question: 2. Which of the following statements best explains why the manganese level was at its lowest on Day 3 at Outlet 2 ?

choices.A: Manganese is used as a nutrient by the plants in the marshes.
choices.B: Manganese levels are lowered through dilution with rainwater.
choices.C: Manganese cannot be dissolved in water.
choices.D: Manganese is no longer seeping from the coal mine site.

questions.title: I
questions.article:
Two artificial marshes were built to help reduce the amounts of iron and manganese in, and the acidity of, water seeping into a stream from a coal mine site (see Figure 1). Table 1 shows precipitation, in centimeters (cm); flow rate, in liters per minute (L/min); pH (acidity); and iron and manganese content, in milligrams per liter (mg/L), of inlet and outlet water over 5 days.



Water having a higher level of iron or manganese or a lower pH than the values given in Table 2 is said to be contaminated.
questions.question: 3. Which of the following statements about Outlet 1 and Outlet 2 flow rates is supported by the data in Table 1 ?

choices.A: Outlet 1 and 2 flow rates both increased during heavy rain.
choices.B: Outlet 1 and 2 flow rates both decreased during heavy rain.
choices.C: Outlet 1 and 2 flow rates did not change during heavy rain.
choices.D: Outlet 1 and 2 flow rates returned to their Day 2 levels the day after the heavy rain.

questions.title: I
questions.article:
Two artificial marshes were built to help reduce the amounts of iron and manganese in, and the acidity of, water seeping into a stream from a coal mine site (see Figure 1). Table 1 shows precipitation, in centimeters (cm); flow rate, in liters per minute (L/min); pH (acidity); and iron and manganese content, in milligrams per liter (mg/L), of inlet and outlet water over 5 days.



Water having a higher level of iron or manganese or a lower pH than the values given in Table 2 is said to be contaminated.
questions.question: 4. According to the information provided in Tables 1 and 2, on any given day, the water leaving the marshes at Outlet 2 is contaminated with respect to:

choices.A: iron only.
choices.B: manganese only.
choices.C: iron and manganese only.
choices.D: manganese and pH only.

questions.title: I
questions.article:
Two artificial marshes were built to help reduce the amounts of iron and manganese in, and the acidity of, water seeping into a stream from a coal mine site (see Figure 1). Table 1 shows precipitation, in centimeters (cm); flow rate, in liters per minute (L/min); pH (acidity); and iron and manganese content, in milligrams per liter (mg/L), of inlet and outlet water over 5 days.



Water having a higher level of iron or manganese or a lower pH than the values given in Table 2 is said to be contaminated.
questions.question: 5. According to the data, which of the following actions would be most useful in reducing the iron levels in water released to the stream to a level below the allowed contaminant level given in Table 2 ?

choices.A: Building a third marsh
choices.B: Removing the second marsh
choices.C: Removing the marshes entirely
choices.D: Rerouting the stream

questions.title: II
questions.article:
An acid-base titration involves slowly adding a measured amount of acid to a solution containing a base and an indicator. The indicator, a dye, signals the endpoint (exact point where the acid has consumed all of the base) by changing colors as the solution goes from basic to acidic. The pH scale is a relative measure of the strength of acids and bases (see Figure 1). Table 1 shows the amount of acid required to reach the endpoint of different basic solutions containing various natural indicators.



Figure adapted from J. Dudley Herron et al., Heath Chemistry. ©1987 by D.C. Heath and Company.
questions.question: 6. Based on the information in Table 1, which of the following indicators experienced the greatest change in pH during the titration?

choices.A: Spinach
choices.B: Tea
choices.C: Beets
choices.D: Apple

questions.title: II
questions.article:

The pH scale is a relative measure of the strength of acids and bases (see Figure 1). Table 1 shows the amount of acid required to reach the endpoint of different basic solutions containing various natural indicators.



Figure adapted from J. Dudley Herron et al., Heath Chemistry. ©1987 by D.C. Heath and Company.
questions.question: 7. According to Figure 1, which of the following solutions is the most acidic?

choices.A: Oven cleaner
choices.B: Baking soda
choices.C: Lemon juice
choices.D: Rainwater

questions.title: II
questions.article:

Figure adapted from J. Dudley Herron et al., Heath Chemistry. ©1987 by D.C. Heath and Company.
questions.question: 8. Which of the following statements about the pH of the basic solutions before and after the titration is consistent with the data in Table 1 ?

choices.A: The pH of a solution is lower after the titration because of the addition of a base.
choices.B: The pH of a solution is lower after the titration because of the addition of an acid.
choices.C: The pH of a solution is higher before the titration because of the addition of an acid.
choices.D: The pH of a solution is higher before the titration because of the addition of the indicator.

questions.title: II
questions.article:

questions.question: 9. If the solutions were reversed and the base was added to an acid solution in the presence of an indicator, based on the information in Table 1, one would predict which of the following results?

choices.A: The pH changes in the opposite direction, but the same color change occurs.
choices.B: The pH changes in the opposite direction and the colors would be reversed.
choices.C: The pH changes in the same direction, but the colors would be reversed.
choices.D: The pH changes in the same direction and the same color change occurs.

questions.article:

questions.question: 10. Strongly acidic or basic solutions have pH values near either end of the pH scale. According to the data in Table 1, which of the following indicators changes at the most acidic pH ?

choices.A: Grape juice
choices.B: Onion
choices.C: Red cabbage
choices.D: Tea

questions.title: III
questions.article:
Many individuals past the age of 45 develop osteoporosis, which makes the bones less dense and is characterized by a net loss of calcium in the bones. Although osteoporosis occurs in men, it is more common in women. Several hypotheses have been proposed to explain the onset of osteoporosis.

Dietary Hypothesis

Calcium from food is absorbed into the bloodstream by the small intestine. Vitamin D is necessary for this process. Most Americans ingest too little calcium and vitamin D in their diet. In a study of individuals 18-25 years old, it was shown that the majority had significantly low levels of calcium in their blood. When these individuals received daily supplements of 1,500 mg of calcium and 400 units of vitamin D, their blood calcium levels increased to normal levels. If insufficient levels of calcium and vitamin D are supplied by the diet, dietary supplements should be taken to avoid osteoporosis.

Estrogen Hypothesis

Estrogens, hormones produced primarily in the ovaries in women and, to a much lesser degree, in the adrenal glands in both sexes, and androgens, produced in the testes in men, are required for the deposition of calcium into bone. Androgen levels in men remain relatively constant throughout life; estrogen levels in women slowly decline after the onset of menopause (the time when a woman's ability to reproduce ends), which usually occurs between the ages of 45 and 55. As a result, the bones of postmenopausal women lose calcium.

Scientists compared the bone density of 4 groups of postmenopausal women. Each group took a dietary supplement. The results are shown in the table.


Exercise Hypothesis

Lack of exercise results in calcium loss from bones, whereas regular weight-bearing exercise can increase bone density. One study showed that 8 weeks of weight training added calcium and hardened bones in both postmenopausal women and men over the age of 45. Since body weight is supported by water, 8 weeks of swimming had no effect on bone density. Both groups followed the same high-calcium diet. Vitamin D intake was not measured.
questions.question: 11. To accept the evidence presented in the Dietary Hypothesis, one must assume that low blood levels of calcium are indicative of:

choices.A: low bone levels of calcium.
choices.B: low bone levels of estrogen.
choices.C: high intestinal levels of vitamin D.
choices.D: high blood levels of vitamin D.

questions.article:

questions.question: 12. One advantage of the Estrogen Hypothesis is that, of the three hypotheses, it best explains why osteoporosis is more common in which of the following groups?

choices.A: Men over the age of 45 rather than in women over the age of 45
choices.B: Men over the age of 45 rather than in men under the age of 45
choices.C: Women over the age of 45 rather than in men over the age of 45
choices.D: Women under the age of 45 rather than in women over the age of 45

questions.title: III
questions.article:

questions.question: 13. According to the Estrogen Hypothesis, premenopausal women who have had their ovaries surgically removed should exhibit:

choices.A: increased calcium levels in their bones.
choices.B: increased estrogen levels in their blood.
choices.C: gradual loss of calcium from their bones.
choices.D: gradual reduction in vitamin D levels in their blood.

questions.question: 14. Which of the following is a criticism that supporters of the Dietary Hypothesis would make of the experimental results cited in the Exercise Hypothesis?

choices.A: Too much calcium was added to the diets of the test subjects in both groups.
choices.B: Blood vitamin D levels in the two groups were not monitored.
choices.C: Estrogen supplements should have been given to each group of individuals.
choices.D: Osteoporosis is more common in premenopausal women than in postmenopausal women.

questions.question: 15. Assume that increased blood calcium levels result in increased bone density. How would supporters of the Estrogen Hypothesis explain the experimental results presented in. the Dietary Hypothesis?

choices.A: The test subjects probably had below-normal blood calcium levels.
choices.B: The test subjects did not perform any weight-bearing exercise.
choices.C: The test subjects probably had normal estrogen and androgen levels.
choices.D: The test subjects were given too low a dosage of vitamin D.

questions.question: 16.  How would supporters of the Dietary Hypothesis explain the results for Group B in the experiment cited in the Estrogen Hypothesis?

choices.A: Vitamin D supplements should not have been taken by this group.
choices.B: Insufficient calcium was added to the diet to increase bone density.
choices.C: Estrogen supplements should have been taken to increase bone density.
choices.D: Too much estrogen was added to the diet of this group to affect bone density.

questions.question: 17.  The experiments cited in the Estrogen Hypothesis and in the Exercise Hypothesis are similar in that each:

choices.A: test subject was given an estrogen supplement.
choices.B: test subject was given a calcium supplement.
choices.C: test subject was given a vitamin D supplement.
choices.D: woman tested was postmenopausal.

questions.title: IV
questions.article:
Three studies were conducted to examine the relationship between ants and the acacia trees they inhabit.

Study 1

Table 1 shows the results of a comparison between a species of acacia tree that is inhabited by ants (ant trees) and a species that is not inhabited by ants (non-ant trees).


Study 2

Table 2 shows the results of a comparison between acacia ants and a closely related ant species that does not inhabit acacia trees.


Study 3

Acacia trees were divided into three groups. Acacia ants were removed from the trees in Group A, but were left on the trees in Group B. Group C consisted of a species of non-ant acacia tree. All the trees were initially healthy and of similar size. The number of trees still alive in each group 300 days after the start of the study is shown in Table 3.


Trees in Group A were killed by plant-eating insects and large mammals that ate the leaves on lower branches. There was no evidence that trees in Groups B and C were killed by grazing animals.
questions.question: 18. How is the design of Study 1 different from the design of Study 2 ?

choices.A: In Study 1, acacia ants were removed from acacia trees, but not in Study 2.
choices.B: In Study 1, plant characteristics were examined, while in Study 2, ant characteristics were examined.
choices.C: In Study 1, acacia ants were examined, while in Study 2, non-acacia ants were examined.
choices.D: In Study 1, ant characteristics were examined, while in Study 2, plant characteristics were examined.

questions.title: IV
questions.article:

Study 1

Table 1 shows the results of a comparison between a species of acacia tree that is inhabited by ants (ant trees) and a species that is not inhabited by ants (non-ant trees).

Trees in Group A were killed by plant-eating insects and large mammals that ate the leaves on lower branches. There was no evidence that trees in Groups B and C were killed by grazing animals.
questions.question: 19. On the basis of the experimental results, one can generalize that which of the following characteristics protects non-ant acacias from being eaten by insects or grazing animals?

choices.A: Bitter-tasting chemicals
choices.B: Protein bodies
choices.C: Extrafloral nectaries
choices.D: Specialized hollow thorns

questions.question: 20. From the results of Study 2 the researchers would hypothesize that the ground surrounding the ant acacia trees was bare of vegetation because the:

choices.A: acacia ants killed the plants growing near the ant acacia trees.
choices.B: acacia ants killed the plants growing near the nonant acacia trees.
choices.C: non-acacia ants killed the plants growing near the non-ant acacia trees.
choices.D: non-acacia ants killed the ant acacia trees.

questions.title: IV
questions.article:
Three studies were conducted to examine the relationship between ants and the acacia trees they inhabit.

Study 1

Table 1 shows the results of a comparison between a species of acacia tree that is inhabited by ants (ant trees) and a species that is not inhabited by ants (non-ant trees).


Study 2

Table 2 shows the results of a comparison between acacia ants and a closely related ant species that does not inhabit acacia trees.


Study 3

Acacia trees were divided into three groups. Acacia ants were removed from the trees in Group A, but were left on the trees in Group B. Group C consisted of a species of non-ant acacia tree. All the trees were initially healthy and of similar size. The number of trees still alive in each group 300 days after the start of the study is shown in Table 3.


Trees in Group A were killed by plant-eating insects and large mammals that ate the leaves on lower branches. There was no evidence that trees in Groups B and C were killed by grazing animals.
questions.question: 21. Can any conclusions about the relationship between plants and insects be drawn from the observations made on acacias and ants?

choices.A: Yes; the behavior of different insect species toward plants seems to be the same.
choices.B: Yes; some plants apparently provide shelter for the insects that protect them.
choices.C: No; plants apparently have the same species of insects living on them.
choices.D: No; insects are rarely associated with plants.

questions.article:

Trees in Group A were killed by plant-eating insects and large mammals that ate the leaves on lower branches. There was no evidence that trees in Groups B and C were killed by grazing animals.
questions.question: 22. Researchers removed all the insects from a tree that is different from the acacia. A comparison showed that few leaves were eaten both before and after removal of the insects. Which of the following conclusions about the insects and the tree best explains these results?

choices.A: The leaves were protected from grazing by some factor other than the insects.
choices.B: Numerous vines grew over the tree and covered the leaves and steins.
choices.C: The tree was unable to defend its leaves from attacks by grazing animals.
choices.D: Aggressive insects attacked any potential grazers on the leaves of this tree.

questions.title: IV
questions.article:
Three studies were conducted to examine the relationship between ants and the acacia trees they inhabit.

Study 1

Table 1 shows the results of a comparison between a species of acacia tree that is inhabited by ants (ant trees) and a species that is not inhabited by ants (non-ant trees).


Study 2

Table 2 shows the results of a comparison between acacia ants and a closely related ant species that does not inhabit acacia trees.


Study 3

Acacia trees were divided into three groups. Acacia ants were removed from the trees in Group A, but were left on the trees in Group B. Group C consisted of a species of non-ant acacia tree. All the trees were initially healthy and of similar size. The number of trees still alive in each group 300 days after the start of the study is shown in Table 3.


Trees in Group A were killed by plant-eating insects and large mammals that ate the leaves on lower branches. There was no evidence that trees in Groups B and C were killed by grazing animals.
questions.question: 23. Which of the following conclusions about the function of protein bodies and extrafloral nectaries would be consistent with the results of the studies?

choices.A: Protein bodies are used to deter grazing animals, while extrafloral nectaries are used as a food source by acacia ants.
choices.B: Extrafloral nectaries are used to deter grazing animals, while protein bodies are used as a food source by acacia ants.
choices.C: Both protein bodies and extrafloral nectaries are used to deter grazing animals.
choices.D: Both protein bodies and extrafloral nectaries are used as food sources by acacia ants.

questions.title: V
questions.article:
A solution is a mixture of at least two substances. The solvent does the dissolving and the solute is dissolved by the solvent.

Some solutions containing solutes, called electrolytes, can conduct electricity because they can carry an electric charge when in solution; whereas nonelectrolytes cannot carry an electric charge. An ammeter is a device used to measure the current carried by a solution (see Figure 1).


The following experiments were performed to test the hypothesis that either increasing the amount of solute or the temperature of the solution will increase the solution's conductivity.

Experiment 1

The solutions consisted of 5.0 grams (g) of each solute dissolved in 100 milliliters (mL) of water at 20°C. The water was also tested without any solute. The results are shown in Table 1.


Experiment 2

Experiment 1 was repeated, except the amount of solute of each solution was increased to 10.0 g in 100 mL of water at 20°C. The results are shown in Table 2.


Experiment 3

Experiment 2 was repeated at 50°C. The results are shown in Table 3.
questions.question: 24. The experimental results for each of the following solutes supports the scientist’s hypothesis that increasing the amount of solute increases the conductivity of a solution EXCEPT the results for:

choices.A: HCI.
choices.C: KCI.
choices.D: Mg(C2H3O2)2.

questions.article:

Experiment 3

questions.question: 25. According to the results of all 3 experiments, which of the following solutions of Mg(C2H3O2)2 would be expected to conduct the most electricity?

choices.A: 2 gin 200 mL of 5°C H2O
choices.B: 10 gin 100 mL of 5°C H2O
choices.C: 10 gin 100 mL of 15°C H2O
choices.D: 20 gin 1,000 mL of 2°C H2O

questions.question: 26.  If a scientist dissolved both 10 g of C12H22O11 and 10 g of KC1 in 100 mL of H2O at 50°C, the ammeter would read approximately:

choices.A: 0.0 milliamps.
choices.B: 1.7 milliamps.
choices.C: 7.4 milliamps.
choices.D: 8.9 milliamps.

questions.question: 27. If Experiment 3 was repeated and the temperature of the H2O was increased to 80°C, the conductivity of the solutions with electrolytes would most likely:

choices.A: decrease with the exception of HC1.
choices.B: remain constant.
choices.C: increase only.
choices.D: increase with the exception of HC1.

questions.question: 28. Which of the following best explains why H2O was tested in all three experiments?

choices.A: To determine if H2O is the solute or the solvent
choices.B: To determine the amount of conductivity contributed by the solvent
choices.C: To determine if H2O will dissolve all of the salts equally
choices.D: To prove that H2O is a good conductor of electricity

questions.question: 29. On the basis of the experimental results, which of the following effects would be most appropriate to test next to gain additional information about conductivity?

choices.A: The effect of temperature on conductivity
choices.B: The effect of solute color on conductivity
choices.C: The effect of water on conductivity
choices.D: The effect of different solvents on conductivity

questions.title: VI
questions.article:
Various chains were released from rest with their lower end touching a scale that measured the force, in newtons (N), of the chain on the scale pan (see Figure 1). A newton is the force required to accelerate a 1-kilogram mass at a rate of 1.0 m/sec2. The mass of the chain, its total length (L), the momentary length of chain on the pan (x), as well as the momentary weight of the portion of the chain on the pan, were also measured. The results are shown in Table 1.



Figure 1 and Table 1 adapted from John R. Gordon and Raymond A. Serway, Physics for Scientists and Engineers with Modern Physics, 3rd edition. ©1990 by Saunders College Publishing.
questions.question: 30. In Trials 5-8, as the momentary length of chain on the pan increases, the momentary weight of the chain on the pan:

choices.A: increases.
choices.B: decreases.
choices.C: remains constant.
choices.D: increases and then decreases.

questions.title: VI
questions.article:
Various chains were released from rest with their lower end touching a scale that measured the force, in newtons (N), of the chain on the scale pan (see Figure 1). A newton is the force required to accelerate a 1-kilogram mass at a rate of 1.0 m/sec2. The mass of the chain, its total length (L), the momentary length of chain on the pan (x), as well as the momentary weight of the portion of the chain on the pan, were also measured. The results are shown in Table 1.



Figure 1 and Table 1 adapted from John R. Gordon and Raymond A. Serway, Physics for Scientists and Engineers with Modern Physics, 3rd edition. ©1990 by Saunders College Publishing.
questions.question: 31. Which of the following trials best supports the hypothesis that doubling the mass of a chain while keeping the length of chain on the pan constant doubles the force on the pan?

choices.A: Trials 1 and 4
choices.B: Trials 2 and 9
choices.C: Trials 2 and 14
choices.D: Trials 3 and 7

questions.article:

questions.question: 32. Based on the data in Table 1, if a chain with a mass of 1, 250 g and a total length of 2.0 m were used, in which of the following ranges would the force on the pan be if x = 1.5 m ?

choices.D: Greater than 22.05 N

choices.A: Trials 5-8
choices.B: Trial 9
choices.C: Trial 11
choices.D: Trial 14

questions.question: 34. If, in Trials 1-4, the entire length of chain (0.5 m) would have been allowed to drop on the scale pan, the momentary weight on the pan for this new trial would have been approximately:

questions.title: VII
questions.article:
Early on May 18, 1980, Mount St. Helens violently erupted, expelling a huge cloud of volcanic ash. Most of the ash fell to Earth on May 18, as the cloud moved rapidly away from the volcano. The following studies examined the ashfall.

Study 1

Researchers measured the depth of uncompacted ash, in millimeters (mm), at hundreds of stations in Washington, Idaho, and Montana. Only ash that had fallen on manufactured objects such as roofs and cars was measured. The results are shown in Figure 1.


Study 2

The thickness of the ash layer on manufactured objects was measured at 14 stations along a north-south line passing near Moscow, Idaho (see Figure 1).

Researchers found that ash deposits east of Yakima, Washington, were composed of two different layers. The thin lower layer (1-2 mm) was made of dark gray ash composed of sand-sized particles of fragmented volcanic rock, and, above that, a thicker layer of lighter-colored ash was composed of smaller (silt-sized) particles (see Figure 2).


It was believed that the dark ash formed during the initial eruption, when rock from the mountain was pulverized, whereas the lighter-colored ash formed later in the eruption as molten rock (magma) inside the volcano was violently expelled.

Study 3

Samples of volcanic ash were collected along a line of stations stretching from the volcano to western Montana. Figure 3 shows the calculated average particle size of the samples at each station.

(Note: The average grain size in Figure 3 includes particles of both dark and light ash.)


Figures adapted from A. M. Sarna-Wojcicki et al., "Areal Distribution, Thickness, Mass, Volume, and Grain Size of Air-fall Ash from the Six Major Eruptions of 1980.” ©1982 by the U. S. Geological Survey.
questions.question: 35. The researchers in Study 2 hypothesized that the dark ash was ejected before the light gray ash. An alternative hypothesis is that both ash types were expelled simultaneously, but that the darker particles were more dense ("heavier") and fell to the ground more rapidly. Which of the following findings would disprove the alternative hypothesis?

choices.A: A light ash layer under a dark ash layer
choices.B: A dark ash layer under a light ash layer
choices.C: Light ash ejected higher into the air than dark ash
choices.D: Light ash deposits found farther from the volcano than dark ash deposits

questions.title: VII
questions.article:

questions.question: 36. Which of the following was varied in Study 3 ?

choices.A: Size of the sample taken
choices.B: Location of sites from which ash samples were taken
choices.C: Method of determining the average ash particle diameter
choices.D: Mass of ash particles per cubic millimeter of ash

questions.article:

Figures adapted from A. M. Sarna-Wojcicki et al., "Areal Distribution, Thickness, Mass, Volume, and Grain Size of Air-fall Ash from the Six Major Eruptions of 1980.” ©1982 by the U. S. Geological Survey.
questions.question: 37. Do the results of Study 1 support the hypothesis that volcanic ash rises into the atmosphere and settles out evenly in a fairly circular region around the erupting volcano?

choices.A: No; the ash layer varied in thickness and was deposited mainly east of the peak.
choices.B: No; the ash layer was of a constant thickness throughout the area of deposition and was deposited along a relatively narrow path east of the peak.
choices.C: Yes; the ash layer varied in thickness and was deposited in a circular pattern around the peak.
choices.D: Yes; the ash layer was of constant thickness and was deposited in a circular pattern around the peak.

questions.question: 38. Based on Study 3, what can one conclude about how average ash particle diameter changed with distance from Mount St. Helens?I. It decreased between -50 and 200 km.II. It increased between 325 and 450 km.III. It decreased between 500 and 700 km.

choices.A: I only
choices.B: II only
choices.C: III only
choices.D: I, II, and III

questions.question: 39. If Study 2 were repeated along a north-south line passing through Ritzville, Washington (shown in Figure 1), compared to the results from the line passing through Moscow, those from Ritzville would show:

choices.A: a maximum thickness of ash greater than 25 mm.
choices.B: no dark ash at any of the measurement sites.
choices.C: no light ash at any of the measurement sites.
choices.D: a thinner ash layer in the center part of the line than at the ends of it.

questions.question: 40. Investigators believed that most of the deposited ash resulted from fragmentation of new rock formed during the eruption rather than fragmentation of much older, preexisting rock. Which of the following studies support(s) this interpretation?

choices.A: Study 2 only
choices.B: Study 3 only
choices.C: Studies 1 and 2 only
choices.D: Studies 2 and 3 only
